X.T: evogeneao.com
Kew Tree of Life Explorer
History of the Earth
OneZoom
Something Other Than Adaptation Could Be Driving Evolution
X.ST: What explains the incredible variety of life on Earth? It seems obvious. Evolution, of course! But perhaps not the evolution most people grew up with. Some ecologists say the theory needs an update: They've proposed a new dynamic driving the emergence of new species, one that doesn't require adaptations or the fittest's survival.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Researchers have modelled the evolution of greenish warblers, a ring species, and showed that natural selection is not necessary to create new species: this would confirm the "neutral biodiversity" theory.

X.T: New Algorithms Force Scientists to Revise the Tree of Life
X.ST: More genetic data is available than ever before to help build evolutionary trees, but scientists are finding that different genes even in the same organism can tell conflicting stories.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: New algorithms determine the genes carrying the most information to build the phylogenetic tree.

X.T: [Hervé Le Guyader] Comment « Penser l’évolution » ?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some information on the history of the theory of evolution.

X.T: What is the Evidence for Evolution?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some proofs of the evolution using the example of cetaceans.

X.T: L'intolérance au lactose est-elle une maladie ?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: How a genetic variation enabling adult humans to drink milk quickly progressed in some populations.

X.T: [Pierre Jouventin] La face cachée de Darwin

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A rather messy presentation of the impact of the theory of evolution on politics and on the society.

X.T: What Caused Life's Major Evolutionary Transitions?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Viroids, endosymbiotic theory, multicellular organisms, and colonies.

X.T: Scientists Catch Jumping Genes Rewiring Genomes
X.ST: Transcription factors that act throughout the genome can arise from mashups of transposable elements inserted into established genes.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Transposons may explain how transcription factors appeared during evolution.

X.T: How Do New Organs Evolve? A Beetle Gland Shows the Way.
X.ST: The evolution of a defensive gland in beetles shows how organs can arise from novel cells carving out new functional niches for their neighbors.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says it all.

X.T: How the Starfish Got Its Arms

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The origin of starfishes.

X.T: Mathematical Analysis of Fruit Fly Wings Hints at Evolution’s Limits
X.ST: A painstaking study of wing morphology shows both the striking uniformity of individuals in a species and a subtle pattern of linked variations that evolution can exploit.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A study of drosophila wings shows that they variates only on a small set of characteristics.

X.T: Single Cells Evolve Large Multicellular Forms in Just Two Years
X.ST: Researchers have discovered that environments favoring clumpy growth are all that’s needed to quickly transform single-celled yeast into complex multicellular organisms.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Researchers have been able to make yeast evolve to group cells into large into large clusters.

X.T: How Did Multicellular Life Evolve?
X.ST: One of the most important events in the history of life on Earth was the emergence of multicellularity. In this episode, Will Ratcliff discusses how his snowflake yeast models provide insight into what drove the transition from single-celled to multicellular organisms.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An interview of WillRatcliff who describes his research on the apparition of multicellularity.

X.T: What Was The "Boring Billion" Really Like?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The period between 1.8 and 0.8 billion years: Canfield ocean, tectonic stability, climatic stasis…

X.T: L'ADN des fossiles : Une machine à remonter le temps

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some examples of discoveries done from analysing old DNA.

X.T: Sponge Genes Hint at the Origins of Neurons and Other Cells
X.ST: A new study of gene expression in sponges reveals the complex diversity of their cells as well as some possibly ancient connections between the nervous, immune and digestive systems.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The subtitle says it all.

X.T: Origin of the Genetic Code: What we do and do not know

ARTICLE.COMMENT: JonPerry proposes to StephenWoodford some corrections on the arguments he uses for fighting the creationism nonsense and gives some information about the origin of the ribosome.

X.T: What Was The First Complex Life on Earth?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The history of the hunt for the oldest fossils, in particular the eukaryote ones.

X.T: A Solution to the Faint-Sun Paradox Reveals a Narrow Window for Life
X.ST: Back when the sun was 30% dimmer, Earth should have frozen solid. Yet water flowed and life blossomed. The solution to the paradox shows that we might have that faint sun to owe for life’s existence — with critical consequences for the possibility of life outside Earth.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The greenhouse effect of CO2 and the energy of huge tidal waves may explain the early Earth temperature.

X.T: Did Eating Insects Shrink These Dinos?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Alvarezsaurids were small, insect eating dinosaurs.

X.T: A New Database Reveals How Much Humans Are Messing With Evolution
X.ST: Some animals and plants are rapidly adapting to our warming, polluted world. How alarming that is depends on your perspective.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The subtitle says it all.

X.T: What Was The Earth Like 1 Billion Years Ago?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Life in oceans and lakes 1000000 years ago.

X.T: An asteroid killed dinosaurs in spring—which might explain why mammals survived
X.ST: New study sheds light on why species extinction was so selective after the K-Pg impact.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An analysis of some fish fossils shows that the impact was during the Northern Hemisphere spring, so this may explain why some species survived because they were preparing hibernation in the Southern Hemisphere.
